name: Ukamajī Naval Battery Remains
description: Foundations and tunnels built for the Japanese Navy by January 1945, including nine cannons, underground ammunition storage, and an observation post. Located within the Kadena Golf Course area; some tunnels are partly collapsed.

name: Ufusakubaru Old Tomb Complex
description: A group of seventeen old tombs from the Early Modern and Modern Periods, built by the people of Hanzan, Hamagawa, and Irei, offering insights into traditional Okinawan burial practices.

name: Sunabe Sākubaru Shell Mound
description: Discovered in 1980, this site revealed Late Kaizuka Period pottery sherds and two stone axes, indicating early human activity in the region.

name: Kadena Air-Raid Surveillance Post Remains
description: Foundations of a surveillance post and part of its fence, serving as a reminder of the island's militarized past during World War II.

name: Kumayā Cave Site
description: A natural cave approximately 40 meters long that served as an air-raid shelter for about 300 people during World War II. It also yielded remains from various periods, including pottery and human remains.

name: Irei-īmuibaru Archaeological Site
description: Contains remains of terraced fields with stone retaining walls dating back to the 12th to 16th centuries, offering a glimpse into the agricultural practices of the time.

name: Shichashīdu Settlement Remains
description: Remains of stone walls of a pre-WWII residence, including traditional Okinawan pigpen latrines (fūru).

name: Hanja-nu-wī Settlement Remains
description: Site includes remains of several residences and roads, as well as the pre-war Chatan Normal School.

name: Uwīsedō/Shichasedō Area Old Tomb Complex
description: Group of 186 tombs, mostly built by residents of Uwīsedō and Shichasedō, dating back to the mid-17th century.

name: Yamagābaru Old Tomb Complex
description: Group of old tombs along Shirahi-gawa River, with funerary urns dating between 1715 and 1725.

name: Ryukyu Turtle-Back Tombs
description: Traditional Ryukyu turtle-back tombs, known as 'kame kōbaka,' reflecting Okinawan ancestral traditions.

name: Kadena Hospital Cave
description: A sealed-off cave adjacent to Kadena AB's golf course, historically used as a Japanese hospital during World War II.

name: Abandoned Tennis Courts
description: Disused tennis courts within Kadena AB, now overtaken by nature, offering a unique glimpse into the passage of time on the base.

name: Okinawan Ancestral Tombs
description: Tombs maintained in collaboration with local communities, especially during the annual Shimi festival, honoring ancestors.

name: Noguni Sokan Shrine
description: A shrine built in 1955 to commemorate the introduction of the sweet potato to Okinawa, featuring Chinese and Ryukyu architectural designs and stone Shishi (lion) statues.

name: Peace Garden Memorial
description: A memorial within Kadena Air Base honoring those who lost their lives during the Battle of Okinawa. It serves as a place of reflection and remembrance for military personnel and civilians.

name: Shirahi-gawa River Historical Area
description: Area along the Shirahi-gawa River with historical tomb complexes and settlement remains, showing centuries of habitation and Okinawan culture.

name: Kadena Flightline Viewing Area
description: While operational, it has historical value due to Kadena AB’s role in the Korean War, Vietnam War, and Cold War air operations.

name: Old Japanese Guard Posts
description: Remnants of Japanese guard posts and fortifications built during WWII, found scattered across certain parts of Kadena AB.
